detaileddescription.para: It is used to define the origin in transformable objects. It is also used to compute coordinates for HUD.
The equations are mapped directly to their OpenGL equivalents, specified by glBlendEquation() or glBlendEquationSeparate().
The factors are mapped directly to their OpenGL equivalents, specified by glBlendFunc() or glBlendFuncSeparate().

briefdescription.para: The alignment of the text in the console.

detaileddescription.para: gf::Direction represents one of the four main directions. A special value is added to represent the center, it indicates no direction.

briefdescription.para: The window was resized (data in event.size)
The window requested to be closed (no data)
A key was pressed (data in event.key)
A key was repeated (data in event.key)
A key was released (data in event.key)
The mouse wheel was scrolled (data in event.mouseWheel)
A mouse button was pressed (data in event.mouseButton)
A mouse button was released (data in event.mouseButton)
The mouse cursor moved (data in event.mouseCursor)
The mouse cursor entered the window (no data)
The mouse cursor left the window (no data)
A gamepad button was pressed (data in event.gamepadButton)
A gamepad button was released (data in event.gamepadButton)
A gamepad axis was moved (data in event.gamepadAxis)
A gamepad was connected (data in event.gamepadConnection)
A gamepad was disconnected (data in event.gamepadDisconnection)
A text was entered (data in event.text)
Enumeration of the different types of events.

detaileddescription.para: The buttons are named after the Xbox 360 controller.
The axis are named after the Xbox 360 controller.
The positive direction is right with a X axis and down with a Y axis.
For triggers, there is only a positive direction.
This identifier is given when a gamepad has just been connected. It must be transformed in a gf::GamepadId with gf::Gamepad::open().
This identifier is the representation of a connected gamepad that has been opened with gf::Gamepad::open(). It is used in the subsequent events related to this gamepad.
These codes corresponds to USB key codes.

briefdescription.para: The cell is visible (computed by FoV)
The cell has been explored (computed by FoV)
A basic algorithm based on ray casting.
Algorithm for computing a field of vision.
The limits are included in the field of vision.
The limits are not included in the field of vision.
Constant to indicate if the limit is part of the field of vision.

detaileddescription.para: The limit is generally a wall that is next to a visible ground cell.
The handler must be kept
The handler can be removed
gf::MessageStatus indicates if a handler should be kept by the message manager or can be removed so that it will not receive any more messages.

briefdescription.para: Another unknown button (may happen with touchpads)

detaileddescription.para: gf::Orientation represents one the four cardinal orientations and the four ordinal (or intercardinal) orientations. A special value is added to represent the center, it indicates no orientation.

briefdescription.para: Same direction as a clock's hands.
Opposite direction of a clock's hands.
The direction of a polygon's rotation.
List of connected lines, a point uses the previous point to form a line.
List of connected lines, a point uses the previous point to form a line, the last point is connected to the first.
List of connected triangles, a point uses the two previous points to form a triangle.
List of connected triangles, a point uses the common center and the previous point to form a triangle.

detaileddescription.para: gf::PrimitiveType represents a kind of primitive to render. The primitives are mapped to their OpenGL equivalents, specified by glDrawArrays or glDrawElements.

briefdescription.para: Stagger index of the hexagonal map.
Stagger axis of the hexagonal map.
the render order of the tiles.
A flag to indicate how to flip a tile in a cell.
The draw order of the objects.
The window can be moved by the user.
The window is scalable by the user.
The window can be closed with an icon in the header.
The window can be minimized with an icon in the header.
The window has a title in the header.
The window's scrollbar can hide automatically.
The window is in the background.
The window's scaler is on the left.
The window can not scale, move or get focus.
Properties for windows and window-like elements.
The row has a dynamic layout.
The row has a static layout.
The tree is a node, generally an internal node of the tree.
The tree is a tabulation, generally the root of the tree.
The button is active as long as it is pressed.
The progress bar can be modified.
Edit widget is currently being modified.
Edit widget is not active and is not being modified.
Edit widget went from state inactive to state active.
Edit widget went from state active to state inactive.
Edit widget has received an enter and lost focus.
A blue and light gray style.
A dark gray and dark blue style.
A type for color controls in a console.

detaileddescription.para: An easing function is a function that specifies how a value changes over time. A normalized easing function has the following properties:
Usual easing functions are provided in gf::Ease.

briefdescription.para: A step is a function with special features.

detaileddescription.para: A step $ f $ is a (mathematical) function which has the following properties:
It can be used to smooth a linear interpolation.

briefdescription.para: A float square matrix of size 2.
A float square matrix of size 3.
A float square matrix of size 4.

detaileddescription.para: gf::MessageHandler is a function that can be called when a message is sent in a message handler. It can be a free function:
It can also be a member function (which is, in fact, the most probable use case).

briefdescription.para: An identifier for a message handler.

detaileddescription.para: gf::Path is a simple typedef for boost::filesystem::path. Boost.Filesystem will eventually be part of the C++17 standard. So, in the future, gf::Path will be a typedef for std::path.

briefdescription.para: Flags composed of edit events properties.
A float color vector with 3 components.
A float color vector with 4 components.
A uint8_t color vector with 3 components.
A uint8_t color vector with 4 components.

memberdef.definition: using gf::Distance = typedef T (*)(Vector<T, N>, Vector<T, N>)
memberdef.name: Distance

detaileddescription.para: A distance function is a function that gives the distance between two vectors.
Blend source and dest according to dest alpha. Also known as alpha blending.
Add source to dest.
Multiply source and dest.
Overwrite dest with source.

briefdescription.para: The constant for color control stop.

detaileddescription.para: An empty cell is transparent and walkable.

briefdescription.para: Get a unit vector from a direction.

simplesect.para: A unit vector representing the direction

briefdescription.para: Get a vector from a direction.

detaileddescription.para: The vector has its coordinates at -1, 0 or 1 depending on the direction. It can be used to represent the displacement on a grid in the given direction.

briefdescription.para: Get an angle from a direction.

detaileddescription.para: Up is at angle 0 and angle grows clockwise.

simplesect.para: an angle (in radians) representing the direction

briefdescription.para: Generate a line between two positions.

detaileddescription.para: This function uses Bresenham's line algorithm.

The last point of the line

detaileddescription.para: The direction is perpendicular to the segment $ [P_0 P_1] $

parameterdescription.para: The initial factor to apply to the displacement
The factor to apply at each iteration

detaileddescription.para: The size can be anything. If the size is not a power of two plus one, then a greater heightmap is generated and a submap of the right size is returned (in the middle of the generated map).

The function takes initial values. If there are less than three values, only the first one is used to initialize the four corners. If there are more than four, only the first four are used to initialize the four corners in that order: north-west, north-east, south-east, south-west. If no values are given, the four corners are initialized to $ 0.0 $.

parameterdescription.para: The initial values of the four corners

detaileddescription.para: The size can be anything. If the size is not a power of two plus one, then a greater heightmap is generated and a submap of the right size is returned (in the middle of the generated map).

The function takes initial values. If there are less than three values, only the first one is used to initialize the four corners. If there are more than four, only the first four are used to initialize the four corners in that order: north-west, north-east, south-east, south-west. If no values are given, the four corners are initialized to $ 0.0 $.

parameterdescription.para: The initial values of the four corners

briefdescription.para: Get an identifier from a string.

briefdescription.para: Get an idenfitier from a string.

detaileddescription.para: The hash is a Fowler–Noll–Vo 1a hash. This function can be used for computing an id at runtime. For computing an id from a string at compile time, you should use the the user-defined literal _id.

This functions returns an interpolated value between two values lhs and rhs according to a parameter $ t $. When $ t = 0 $ then lhs is returned, and when $ t = 1 $ then rhs is returned.

briefdescription.para: Make the current thread sleep for a given duration.

detaileddescription.para: gf::sleep is the best way to block a program or one of its threads, as it doesn't consume any CPU power.
